Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Stability of Colossally Supersaturated Structural Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Case Western Reserve University will collaborate with the University of Birmingham, UK, on novel methods of engineering the surface of structural alloys, including austenitic stainless steel, Ni-Cr, and Co-Cr alloys. Both groups have carried out extensive prior work, which revealed that infusing interstitial solutes - carbon or nitrogen - from the alloy surface at low temperature effectively suppresses the precipitation of second phases and enables the formation of an approximately 25 micrometer thick homogeneous, precipitate-free hard shell ("case") with carbon or nitrogen concentrations that can exceed the equilibrium solubility limit by about 100,000 times (!). Such colossal supersaturation with interstitial makes the surface up to 5 times harder, increases the wear resistance and the fatigue life by about 100 times, and elevates the corrosion resistance to that of the most corrosion-resistant alloys. The new project will focus on the hitherto unexplored reliability and lifetime of these unusual non-equilibrium materials at elevated temperature and under applied mechanical stress. A second thrust the project is to explore the possibility actually using controlled thermal post-processing for further improving the alloy surface properties and durability. Under the high driving force for precipitation it should be possible to generate an ultrafine dispersion of second-phase particles, which is expected to further improve hardness without compromising corrosion resistance.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The usefulness of austenitic stainless steel and related structural alloys for a broad variety of technical applications can be dramatically improved by exposing finished parts of these materials to a process that infuses carbon or nitrogen atoms into their surface. Such "case hardening" was already applied to arms in the middle age. However, while improving the surface hardness, the conventional way in which it was carried out it compromises other properties, e.g. the resistance against damage from repeated loading or chemical impact from the environment. Recently, new concepts have been developed that overcome these limitations. It has been demonstrated that appropriately conducted surface infusion of carbon or nitrogen at low temperature actually dramatically improves all alloy properties because by providing very high concentrations of carbon/nitrogen while suppressing the precipitation of carbide or nitride particles. However, this leaves the alloy in a non-equilibrium state, and hardly anything is known to date about the durability, lifetime, and temperature stability of alloys treated in this way. Moreover, a great potential seems to exist for transforming the non-equilibrium state into one providing further improved alloy properties by tempering the material after the infusion of carbon or nitrogen. Case Western Reserve University will collaborate with another leading group in this field at the University of Birmingham, UK, to develop a fundamental scientific understanding of these highly technologically relevant aspects. This is of great importance for many applications of surface-engineered structural alloys, e. g. for bearings, food processing blades, valves, dies, nuclear reactor components, medical implants, and surgical and dental instruments.

The project is supported by the Metals and Metallic Nanostructures program and the Office of Special Programs, Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important new method to engineer the surface of austenitic stainless steel and related alloys is provided by inward diffusion of carbon or nitrogen at low-temperature. This enables the formation of a ~25 um thick homogeneous, precipitate-free hard shell ("case") with carbon or nitrogen concentrations that can exceed the equilibrium solubility limit by about 100,000 times (!). This makes the surface up to 5 times harder, increases the wear resistance and the fatigue life by about 100 times, and elevates the corrosion resistance to that of the most corrosion-resistant alloys. However, owing to the colossal super saturation with interstitial solute, these unusual materials are very far from thermodynamic equilibrium.

In this joint research project of CWRU (Case Western Reserve University) and UoB (University of Birmingham, UK), we investigated the thermal stability of such surface-engineered alloys. For surface-engineered specimens fabricated by different methods in both laboratories, we studied how the initial concentration--depth profile of interstitial solute and the microstructure respond to heat treatments: (i) Long-term exposure to "moderate" temperatures that only mobilize the interstitial solute and (ii) short-term exposure to "high" temperatures that mobilize both the interstitial solute and the metal atoms of the matrix. Concentration--depth profiles were measured in cross-section by SAM (scanning Auger microprobe), while microstructural changes were observed by XRD (X-ray diffractometry) and TEM (transmission electron microscopy).

Intellectual Merit: The research has generated important new scientific insights and discoveries. The initial hypothesis that solute might be lost to the ambient could be rejected for both types of heat exposure. While in both cases diffusion flattens the concentration--depth profile, it maintains a uniform negative slope from the surface toward the alloy core. This finding is of primary importance for technical applications, as it implies that the alloy will not abruptly lose the superior properties enabled by surface engineering. A surprising discovery was made after long-term moderate-temperature exposure of low-temperature carburized austenitic stainless steel in air: The integral of the concentration--depth profile over the depth apparently increases with time -- suggesting that the alloy assimilates carbon. This unexpected observation led us to carefully analyze potential artifacts of our SAM measurements. As a result, we have developed a SAM simulator and a new theory for the origin of concentration-dependent background in measured concentration--depth profiles. Based on this theory, we have developed a new method to correct the background of SAM concentration--depth profiles. Nevertheless, the apparent uptake of carbon appears to be real.

Short-tem exposure to "high" temperature was found to not only flatten the concentration--depth profile, but also change the microstructure. In the case of low-temperature-carburized austenitic stainless steel, the lattice parameter of the alloy, initially expanded by the interstitially dissolved carbon, relaxes toward its solute-free value. This constitutes indirect evidence for precipitation of carbide. Since direct observation of these particles by transmission electron microscopy did not succeed, it appears that the precipitates on nanoscopic and therefore difficult to detect within very high densities of other structural defects (predominantly dislocations).

Along with the experimental work, we developed two general-purpose computer programs for analysis and quantitative modeling of concentration--depth profiles. One program serves to determine the solute diffusion coefficient and its (extraordinarily strong) dependence on local solute concentration from experimentally acquired concentration--depth profiles by Boltzmann--Matano analysis. The other program serves to simulate the temporal evolution of concentration--depth profiles under strongly concentration-dependent diffusion and arbitrary temporal variation of (i) activity of the diffusing species in the ambient gas, (ii) alloy surface-transparency, and (iii) temperature.

Broader impacts: The project enabled mutual longer-term international exchange of graduate students between CWRU and UoB as well as mutual PI visits. This has laid the foundation for long-term collaboration between our laboratories. The project and our future work have benefited from intense exchange of know-how regarding different methods of surface engineering and scientific techniques. To graduate students and two undergraduate students participated in this work, and it contributed to theses, publications, and coursework at CWRU. The project also enabled the PIs of both institutions to become organizers of an international symposium at which several students of both laboratories presented their work.


Last Modified: 10/30/2016
Modified by: Frank Ernst

This enables the formation of a ~25 um thick homogeneous, precipitate-free hard shell ("case") with carbon or nitrogen concentrations that can exceed the equilibrium solubility limit by about 100,000 times (!). However, owing to the colossal super saturation with interstitial solute, these unusual materials are very far from thermodynamic equilibrium. For surface-engineered specimens fabricated by different methods in both laboratories, we studied how the initial concentration--depth profile of interstitial solute and the microstructure respond to heat treatments: (i) Long-term exposure to "moderate" temperatures that only mobilize the interstitial solute and (ii) short-term exposure to "high" temperatures that mobilize both the interstitial solute and the metal atoms of the matrix. To graduate students and two undergraduate students participated in this work, and it contributed to theses, publications, and coursework at CWRU. The project also enabled the PIs of both institutions to become organizers of an international symposium at which several students of both laboratories presented their work.
